## Principal Components Analysis

### Challenge

*  Examine the `drinks` dataset in the `fivethirtyeight` package.  
*  Do a principal components analysis using only the `beer_servings`, `spirit_servings`, and `wine_servings` columns as input for the PCA. 
*  Make a plot of PC1 against PC2, and another of PC2 against PC3
*  Examine the loadings of the PCA, and interpret the plot.  What to the various axes mean, and what do they tell you about the alcohol consumption of the various countries?

```{r echo=F, include=F}
library(fivethirtyeight)
PCA <- prcomp(drinks[,c(2,3,4)], center = T, scale=T)

library(ggplot2)
forPlot <- data.frame(PCA$x, drinks$country, drinks$total_litres_of_pure_alcohol)

PCA$loadings

ggplot(data=forPlot, aes(x=PC1, y=PC2)) + 
  geom_text(aes(label=drinks.country))

ggplot(data=forPlot, aes(x=PC1, y=PC3)) + 
  geom_text(aes(label=drinks.country))
```
